Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides travel support for student participation in the Symposium on Undergraduate Research to be held at the Laser Science XXXII Conference. This conference is of great importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical physics in the United States because almost all work in this area involves lasers in some way. The support of students through this award makes a substantial contribution to the education and training of future scientists. Students who graduate with a background in atomic, molecular, and optical physics acquire a broad range of knowledge and skills that enable them to contribute to progress in many areas of science and technology.

The Laser Science XXXII Conference, which this award supports, is a joint meeting of the American Physical Society's Division of Laser Science and the Optical Society of America's annual meeting to be held in Rochester, NY in October, 2016. This Conference offers an opportunity for students to present their research results and to interact with senior scientists primarily from the United States, but also the broader international community. Support is provided only for US students (students enrolled in US universities).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The sixteenth annual DLS Symposium on Undergraduate Research at LS-XXXII was held in Rochester, NY on Tuesday, 18 October, 2016.   The Symposium has grown from 10 presentations in 2001 to 51 this year, the largest ever.  These Symposia have brought over 500 students to our meetings to present what are often the first research papers of their budding careers.  Programs, articles, further information, and photos from previous symposiaare at the DLS (APS) website http://www.aps.org/units/dls/meetings/symposium/ .

The 2016 Symposium began with a buffet-style welcoming dinner on Monday evening, 17 October in an especially convenient location because the students who arrived at any time during the evening could check into the hotel and then go directly to the dinner. We were privileged to have the national director of the Society of Physics Students, Brad Conrad, and several of the mentors, as our guests.  Afterwards, students and faculty guests lingered in conversations with each other.   It was a time to make acquaintances with one another, enjoy casual time with the many mentors who were there, and discuss the forthcoming adventure. 

Our events began at noon Tuesday with a sandwich lunch for our participants and very many honored guests, who spoke to the assembled group onmany topics initiated by student questions.  The guests included Nobel Laureates Bill Phillips and John Hall, Schawlow Prize recipient Moti Segev, SPS director Brad Conrad, industrial representative Mike Houk, and mentors Kristan Corwin, Catherine Herne, Chad Hoyt, Janet Hudgings, Hong Lin, and others. The exchanges were lively and stimulating, and the 1:00 PM ending time came all too soon. The students were especially fortunate this year to have so many of the prize recipients and highly visible optical scientists meet and talk with them during the lunch. We heard inspiring remarks and lively discussion from several of these distinguished guests.  

The Symposium events began with the poster session where many of the conference attendees stopped by to talk with the students.  The session included 41 papers whose abstracts were published in an eight-page program, and was presided by Chad Hoyt from Bethel University. The entire area was abuzz with conversation and discussion as the delighted presenters talked about their work to interested scientists and fellow students. 

The oral presentation sessions began at 3:00 and lasted until 6:00. The first one was presided by Janice Hudgings from Pomona College, and the second one was presided by Catherine Herne of SUNY at New Paltz. Besides students and mentors, there were several regular conference attendees. The quality of the talks was uniformly very high, and the two oral sessions were an unqualified success.

 The final Symposium event was a very special farewell dinner sponsored by the University of Rochester. Dinner was followed by a well-prepared presentation by Prof. Miguel Alonso.  The main theme was the history of the Institute of Optics and the opportunities for research as a graduate student. The students were privileged to hear this information from one of the experts.

It was gratifying that these very young scientists could give their first presentations at a professional meeting.   Many students remained at the meeting one or more extra days to hear talks or visit exhibits. Some were thrilled to meet famous and/or highly visible scientists.  Judging from the enthusiastic notes that accompanied their final reports, the students  will remember this opportunity.   Some of the comments were:

  • I had an absolutely amazing time - I learned a ton and met so many people - from undergraduates to grad students, professors, and people in industry (and I wish I could have stayed more time!).
  • I  really enjoyed getting to meet some of the other undergrads as well as grad students and leaders in the field. I particularly liked the talks by undergrads because they were easier to understand with less background knowledge. My favorite part was talking to people with similar academic interests. 
  • This experience helped me a lot. It provided a chance to interact with outstanding scientists as well as successful people from industry. These awesome people firmed my belief that a PhD is beneficial to my career, and that doing physics is a cool thing.
  • Anytime I have ever presented work, it has been for a competition. This was a nice change  where I can casually talk about my project with others who understand optics and genuinely wants to know more about my work.
  • It was an incredible experience and I feel very fortunate to have  interacted with such inspiring minds and make great connections. I met so many brilliant students as well as many professionals who were  warm, inviting, unpretentious, and more than excited to share about their work with an aspiring undergrad. ... The chance to practice my presentation and networking skills was invaluable and I feel much more equipped to get the most out of future conferences.
